title: Epic: Intelligence & Analytics
description: Smart features — compatibility warnings, usage analytics, recommendations, and health diagnostics dashboard.

title: Skill compatibility warnings
description:
Warn users when installing a skill that may be incompatible with their agent or requires tools they haven't enabled.

**Context:** SKILL.md frontmatter already supports `compatibility` and `allowed-tools` fields (parsed by parser.ts). These fields are read and stored but never validated against the user's environment.

**Implementation:**
- On install: check skill's `compatibility` field against the target agent
- Check `allowed-tools` against known tool availability (if detectable)
- Show warning dialog: 'This skill requires tools X and Y which may not be available in your Cursor setup'
- Non-blocking: user can proceed despite warning
- Could also show compatibility badges in marketplace results and detail view
- Tree view: warning icon on incompatible installed skills

title: Skill usage analytics (local tracking)
description:
Track which installed skills are actually being used in agent sessions. Show 'last used' timestamps and identify never-used skills.

**Implementation approaches:**
1. **File access monitoring:** Watch for read access on SKILL.md files (agents read these when invoked)
2. **Lock file timestamps:** Monitor `updatedAt` changes in .skill-lock.json
3. **Session log parsing:** Parse Claude conversation logs for skill invocation patterns (if accessible)
4. **Manual tagging:** Let users mark skills as 'used today' manually

**UI:**
- Tree item decoration: 'Last used: 2 days ago' in tooltip
- 'Never Used' indicator for stale skills — suggest cleanup
- Sort option: 'Sort by last used' in tree view
- Usage statistics in a dedicated panel or status bar

**Privacy:** All tracking is local-only, never sent to any API.

title: Skill recommendations engine
description:
Recommend skills based on context — what the user has installed, their project type, and community patterns.

**Recommendation signals:**
1. **Co-install patterns:** 'Users who installed X also installed Y' (requires skills.sh API support)
2. **Project analysis:** Detect project type from package.json/Cargo.toml/go.mod etc., recommend matching skills
   - React project → react-best-practices, tailwind-v4-shadcn, vitest
   - Python project → relevant Python skills
3. **Gap analysis:** 'You have frontend skills but no testing skill — consider vitest'
4. **Custom source skills:** If a custom source has skills you haven't installed, suggest them

**UI:**
- 'Recommended for You' section in marketplace
- 'Suggested Skills' section in tree view (collapsible, below installed)
- Notification on project open: 'This React project might benefit from 3 skills you don't have'
- Dismiss/snooze per suggestion

title: Skill health dashboard (expanded diagnostics)
description:
Expand the existing getDiagnostics() function into a full webview dashboard showing system health, skill status, and troubleshooting info.

**Current state:** getDiagnostics() in scanner.ts generates a text report on startup. It checks agent directories, subdirectory counts, valid skill counts, and missing workspace state. But it's only shown as a notification.

**Proposed dashboard (webview panel):**
- **Agent Status:** Per-agent directory health (exists, readable, skill count)
- **Skill Health:** For each skill — symlink valid, lock file entry exists, SKILL.md parseable, hash matches remote
- **Broken Symlinks:** List skills with dangling symlinks (already detected as 'untracked')
- **Lock File Integrity:** Validate all entries have required fields, no orphans
- **Update History:** Timeline of installs, updates, uninstalls (from lock file timestamps)
- **Storage Stats:** Total skills, disk usage, per-agent breakdown
- **Quick Actions:** Fix broken symlinks, clean orphaned lock entries, re-scan

**Implementation:** New command `skills-sh.openDiagnostics` opening a webview panel with a dashboard layout.

title: Epic: Marketplace Enhancements
description: Improvements to the skills.sh marketplace webview — category filtering, pagination, search history, and notifications.

title: Server-side category filtering
description:
The `categoryClick` handler in provider.ts is a no-op (empty break). Currently category chips trigger a client-side search command instead. Implement proper server-side filtering so the marketplace can filter by category with dedicated API support, enabling richer category experiences (counts, sub-categories, filtered leaderboards).

**Current state:** `case 'categoryClick': break;` in src/views/marketplace/provider.ts:231
**Desired:** Category selection filters the leaderboard/search results server-side, with category-specific result counts.

title: Infinite scroll / server-side pagination
description:
The `loadMore` handler in provider.ts is a no-op. Pagination state is managed client-side with `currentPage`. Implement true infinite scroll or 'Load More' with server-side pagination support.

**Current state:** `case 'loadMore': break;` in src/views/marketplace/provider.ts:233. Client uses `currentPage` variable.
**Desired:** Clicking 'Load More' or scrolling to bottom fetches next page from API. Supports both leaderboard pagination and search result pagination. Show loading spinner during fetch.

title: Search history and recent searches
description:
Track recent marketplace searches so users can quickly re-access previous queries without retyping.

**Implementation ideas:**
- Store last N searches in extension globalState or workspace state
- Show as dropdown/suggestions below the search input
- Clear history option
- Optionally show 'recent searches' chips on the marketplace home view
- Could also track recently viewed skill detail pages

title: Marketplace new skill notifications
description:
Notify users when new skills are published that match their interests — category preferences, installed skill topics, or followed sources.

**Implementation ideas:**
- On startup (alongside update check), query API for skills published since last check
- Filter by user's configured categories (setting already exists)
- Show notification: '3 new skills this week in your categories'
- Badge on marketplace view icon
- Could also notify when skills from custom sources get new additions
- Store last-check timestamp in globalState

title: Epic: Team & Sharing
description: Features for sharing skills across teams and projects — team sync, export/import, skill bundles/collections.

title: Team skill sync (share skills to project repo)
description:
Make it easy to share a globally-installed skill with your team by copying it into the project's .claude/skills/ directory for git-committed sharing.

**TOP 5 PRIORITY — unique differentiator; no other tool does this well**

**Implementation:**
- New command: 'Share Skill to Project' in context menu for global skills
- Copies skill directory contents (SKILL.md + any supporting files) into .claude/skills/<name>/
- Does NOT create symlink — copies actual files so they can be committed to git
- Optionally opens a git staging view for the new files
- Handles conflicts: warn if .claude/skills/<name>/ already exists
- Reverse direction: 'Import Project Skill to Global' — installs a project skill globally
- Could add a 'Team Skills' section to marketplace showing what skills the project uses

**Context:** The scanner already distinguishes project vs global skills. The industry consensus (Claude Code, Copilot, Cursor) is to commit skills/rules to the repo for team sharing. This extension can be the bridge.
notes: TOP 5 PICK #2: Unique differentiator — no other tool makes it easy to share agent skills with your team via git. The industry is converging on repo-committed skills.

title: Skill export/import (portable skill sets)
description:
Export your installed skill configuration as a shareable file. Teammates can import it to replicate your setup — like 'VS Code Settings Sync' but for agent skills.

**Implementation:**
- Export command: generates a JSON/YAML manifest listing all installed skills with their sources
- Format: `{ skills: [{ name, source, scope, agents }] }` — everything needed to reinstall
- Import command: reads manifest, batch-installs all listed skills
- Could integrate with VS Code Settings Sync if possible
- Export options: all skills, only global, only project, only pinned/favorites
- Import handles: already-installed skills (skip), unavailable sources (warn), version mismatches

**Use cases:**
- New team member onboarding: 'Here's our team's skill config'
- Sharing your personal setup on social media / blog posts
- Backup/restore across machines

title: Skill collections / bundles
description:
Curated sets of skills for specific workflows — install a whole 'React Developer Pack' or 'DevOps Essentials' bundle with one click.

**TOP 5 PRIORITY — multiplier feature for onboarding new developers**

**Implementation options:**
1. **Local bundles:** JSON manifest in custom source repos defining a collection
   ```json
   { "name": "React Developer Pack", "skills": ["react-best-practices", "tailwind-v4-shadcn", "vitest"] }
   ```
2. **skills.sh API:** If skills.sh exposes collection endpoints, integrate natively
3. **Built-in bundles:** Ship a few default collections with the extension
4. **User-defined bundles:** Let users create their own collections from installed skills

**UI:**
- Marketplace section: 'Collections' tab alongside leaderboard/search
- Collection detail view: shows all skills in the bundle with descriptions
- One-click 'Install All' button
- Shows which skills from the bundle are already installed
- Could also surface in the tree view: 'Suggested Collections' based on project type
notes: TOP 5 PICK #4: Multiplier for onboarding. Instead of installing skills one-by-one, new devs get a curated pack for their stack.

title: Epic: Skill Management
description: Core skill lifecycle features — creation, pinning, batch ops, scope management, enable/disable, and auto-updates.

title: Skill Creation Wizard
description:
The 'My Skills' group in the tree detects user-created skills (regular directories, not symlinks), but there's no way to CREATE a new skill from the extension. Add a scaffolding command that generates a properly structured skill.

**TOP 5 PRIORITY — closes the biggest UX gap (consume vs. create)**

**Implementation:**
- New command: `skills-sh.createSkill`
- Quick pick flow: name → description → target agent(s) → scope (project/global)
- Generate SKILL.md with YAML frontmatter template (name, description, compatibility fields)
- Create directory in appropriate location (~/.claude/skills/ or .claude/skills/)
- Open generated SKILL.md in editor for immediate editing
- Optionally scaffold allowed-tools, example prompts sections
- Refresh tree to show new skill under 'My Skills'

**References:** parser.ts already handles SKILL.md frontmatter parsing with gray-matter
notes: TOP 5 PICK #1: Closes the biggest UX gap — the extension helps you consume skills but not create them. This is the most impactful standalone feature.

title: Skill pinning / favorites
description:
Allow users to pin frequently-used skills to the top of the installed skills tree for quick access.

**Implementation:**
- Store pinned skill names in extension globalState
- New context menu action: 'Pin Skill' / 'Unpin Skill' on skill tree items
- Pinned skills appear in a 'Pinned' group at the very top of the tree (above Updates)
- Pin icon in tree item decoration
- Pinned state persists across sessions via globalState
- Simple context value addition: `skill_pinned` for menu visibility

title: Batch operations (multi-select install/uninstall/update)
description:
Support selecting multiple skills for batch operations instead of one-at-a-time actions.

**Implementation:**
- Enable multi-select in tree view (VS Code TreeView supports this natively)
- Context menu actions for multi-select: 'Uninstall Selected', 'Update Selected'
- Marketplace: checkbox selection on search/leaderboard results for batch install
- Confirmation dialog lists all selected skills
- Reuse existing installer patterns — updateSkills() already handles N updates with 2N commands
- Progress notification shows overall batch progress (e.g., '3/7 skills installed')

title: Promote/demote skill scope (project ↔ global)
description:
Move a skill between project scope (.claude/skills/) and global scope (~/.claude/skills/) without uninstalling and reinstalling.

**Implementation:**
- New context menu actions on skill tree items: 'Move to Global' / 'Move to Project'
- For project → global: copy/move skill directory to global path, update symlinks
- For global → project: copy skill into .claude/skills/ in workspace
- Update lock file entries if applicable
- Confirmation dialog explaining the scope change
- Refresh tree after move

**Use case:** Developer discovers a useful project skill and wants to use it everywhere, or wants to share a personal skill with the team by moving it to project scope.

title: Quick skill enable/disable switcher
description:
Enable/disable skills without uninstalling them — useful for context-switching between projects that need different skill sets.

**TOP 5 PRIORITY — practical daily utility for multi-project developers**

**Implementation:**
- Disable = rename SKILL.md → SKILL.md.disabled (or move to a .disabled/ subfolder)
- Scanner ignores disabled skills (no SKILL.md found = not a valid skill)
- Tree view shows disabled skills in a 'Disabled' group with dimmed icon
- Context menu: 'Disable Skill' / 'Enable Skill'
- Command palette: 'Quick Switch Skills' → multi-select checklist of all skills with toggle checkboxes
- Keyboard shortcut for quick access
- Could support 'skill profiles' (named sets of enabled skills) as a future extension

**Alternatives considered:**
- Symlink removal/recreation (too heavy, loses lock file state)
- Config-based disable list (doesn't affect the actual agent, only our UI)
notes: TOP 5 PICK #5: Practical daily utility. Multi-project developers constantly switch contexts — enabling/disabling skills without uninstalling is essential friction reduction.

title: Auto-update mode
description:
Opt-in automatic updates that apply non-breaking skill updates without user intervention.

**Implementation:**
- New setting: `skills-sh.autoUpdate` (boolean, default false)
- When enabled, the startup update check (already exists via `checkUpdatesOnStartup`) automatically applies updates
- Only auto-update skills from trusted sources (skills.sh registry, not custom sources)
- Show notification after auto-updates: 'Updated 3 skills automatically'
- Log all auto-updates to output channel for audit trail
- Respect `confirmBeforeInstall` setting — if true, still prompt even in auto-update mode
- Consider: update only SKILL.md content changes vs structural changes (new files added)

title: Epic: Update System
description: Enhancements to the skill update detection and application workflow — diff previews, auto-updates, changelog display.

title: Update diff preview before applying
description:
Show users what changed in a skill before they apply an update. Currently the update system detects hash changes via GitHub Trees API but provides no visibility into WHAT changed.

**TOP 5 PRIORITY — builds trust in the update system, low effort given existing infra**

**Implementation:**
- When user clicks 'Update' on a skill (or views update details), fetch the remote SKILL.md
- Show a VS Code diff editor: local SKILL.md vs remote SKILL.md
- Could also show a summary: 'Description changed', 'New allowed-tools added', etc.
- For skills with multiple files, show a list of changed files (we already have folder hashes per-file from the Trees API)
- Add 'View Changes' button to the update confirmation dialog
- Optionally: show diff inline in the marketplace detail view

**Existing infra:**
- github.ts:fetchSkillMd() already fetches remote SKILL.md content
- updates.ts:checkUpdates() already has the hash comparison logic
- VS Code has built-in diff editor API: `vscode.commands.executeCommand('vscode.diff', ...)`
notes: TOP 5 PICK #3: Low effort, high trust. Existing infra (fetchSkillMd, VS Code diff API) makes this achievable quickly while building confidence in the update system.

title: Detail page manifest button for non-installed skills
Install Missing banner on Installed tab
Epic: UX Polish
description: UI/UX refinements — tree view enhancements, cross-agent expansion, skill previews, onboarding improvements.

title: Install count display in tree view
description:
The `showInstallCountInTree` setting already exists (default: false) but the tree items don't display install count data. Wire up the marketplace install counts to the tree view.

**Current state:** Setting declared in package.json, checked by code, but no data source connected. The detail-scraper can fetch weekly installs for individual skills, but it's an expensive per-skill scrape.

**Implementation:**
- Option A: Batch query — if skills.sh API supports bulk install count queries, fetch counts for all installed skills in one call
- Option B: Cache on demand — when a skill detail is viewed in marketplace, cache the install count and show it in the tree
- Option C: Lock file enrichment — store install count in lock file when installing, refresh periodically
- Display: Show as description suffix '(1.2k installs)' or as inline badge in tree item
- Respect the `showInstallCountInTree` setting toggle

title: Cross-agent expansion (scan all 13 supported agents)
description:
The marketplace hero section lists 13 agent badges (claude-code, cursor, copilot, codex, windsurf, gemini-cli, opencode, roo, cline, amp, goose, kiro-cli, trae) but only 4 agents are scanned by default. Expand scanning support and agent path detection for more agents.

**Current state:**
- AgentConfig in types.ts defines globalDir + projectDir per agent
- scanAgents setting controls which agents to scan (default: claude, cursor, windsurf, codex)
- Hero badges in marketplace show all 13 agents

**Work needed:**
- Research directory conventions for: copilot, gemini-cli, opencode, roo, cline, amp, goose, kiro-cli, trae
- Add AgentConfig entries for each discovered agent
- Update default `scanAgents` list or auto-detect installed agents
- Test symlink behavior on each agent's skill directory structure
- Update documentation for multi-agent support

title: Skill preview / playground panel
description:
Rich preview of a skill before installing — view SKILL.md content, metadata, compatibility, and allowed tools in a dedicated panel.

**Current state:** The marketplace detail view shows scraped HTML from skills.sh. But there's no way to preview a skill from a custom source, and the detail view is limited to what the scraper extracts.

**Implementation:**
- New command: 'Preview Skill' — opens a webview panel with rich skill preview
- For marketplace skills: enhanced detail view with structured metadata display
- For custom source skills: fetch SKILL.md via GitHub API and render locally
- Show: name, description, compatibility matrix, allowed-tools list, full SKILL.md rendered, file tree of the skill directory
- 'Try Before Install' concept: could temporarily copy skill to a sandbox directory for one session
- Compare panel: side-by-side preview of two similar skills to help choose

title: Welcome / onboarding experience
description:
First-run experience for new users that introduces the extension's capabilities and guides setup.

**Trigger:** Show on first activation (track in globalState) or when no skills are installed.

**Onboarding flow:**
1. Welcome panel explaining what agent skills are
2. Quick setup: select your agents (Claude, Cursor, etc.)
3. Starter pack suggestion: offer to install a popular bundle
4. Custom source setup: guide adding a GitHub repo
5. Quick tour: highlight tree view, marketplace, update checking

**Implementation:**
- Webview-based walkthrough panel (not just notifications)
- 'Get Started' button in empty tree state (when `skills-sh.noSkillsFound` context is true)
- Don't show again / skip options
- Could use VS Code's native walkthrough contribution point (package.json walkthroughs)

title: Keyboard shortcuts for common operations
description:
Add keyboard shortcuts for frequently-used commands to speed up power-user workflows.

**Proposed keybindings:**
- Search marketplace: Ctrl+Shift+K (or similar available binding)
- Refresh installed: Ctrl+Shift+R (within skills view focus)
- Check updates: no default binding, user-configurable
- Quick skill switcher (enable/disable): Ctrl+Shift+S (depends on enable/disable feature)

**Implementation:**
- Declare keybindings in package.json contributes.keybindings
- Use `when` clauses to scope bindings appropriately (e.g., when skills view is focused)
- Document shortcuts in README
- Ensure no conflicts with common VS Code bindings

title: Tree view sorting options
description:
Add sorting options to the installed skills tree view beyond the current source-based grouping.

**Sort options:**
- By source (current default)
- Alphabetical (A-Z / Z-A)
- By install date (newest first / oldest first)
- By last updated
- By agent
- By scope (global first / project first)

**Implementation:**
- Add sort dropdown or cycle button to tree view title actions
- Store selected sort in globalState for persistence
- Modify InstalledSkillsTreeProvider to sort based on selection
- Could combine with filter: 'Show only Claude skills', 'Show only global skills'
